review.title: A Hierarchical Dirichlet Process Model with Multiple Levels of Clustering for Human EEG Seizure Modeling
review.abstract: Driven by the multi-level structure of human intracranial electroencephalogram (iEEG) recordings of epileptic seizures, we introduce a new variant of a hierarchical Dirichlet Process---the multi-level clustering hierarchical Dirichlet Process (MLC-HDP)---that simultaneously clusters datasets on multiple levels. Our seizure dataset contains brain activity recorded in typically more than a hundred individual channels for each seizure of each patient. The MLC-HDP model clusters over channels-types, seizure-types, and patient-types simultaneously. We describe this model and its implementation in detail. We also present the results of a simulation study comparing the MLC-HDP to a similar model, the Nested Dirichlet Process and finally demonstrate the MLC-HDP's use in modeling seizures across multiple patients. We find the MLC-HDP's clustering to be comparable to independent human physician clusterings. To our knowledge, the MLC-HDP model is the first in the epilepsy literature capable of clustering seizures within and between patients.

sections.heading: 4.1. Simulated data
sections.text: In order to explore some of the characteristics of the MLC-HDP in a controlled environment and to compare it with a similar model, we conducted a two-stage version of it based on the same simulated data presented in (Rodr ́ íguez et al. 2008) and implemented the model of the nested dirichlet process described in their work. sections.heading: 4.2. Human seizures on intracranial EEG
sections.text: We compiled a dataset of 193 intracranial EEG seizure data on 10 randomly selected patients from the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia because these patients exhibit characteristics commonly used in epilepsy intracranial EEG sets. Table 2 describes the number of seizures per patient as well as the number of seizures per patient and the differences in the number of usable channels within9We have all channel activity from -30 to + 90 seconds around the clinically marked onset of each patient. We have calculated a set of simple and intuitive features for each channel: the log10 power in four clinically relevant frequency bands (4-8, 8-13 Hz).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: We describe a new hierarchical variant of the Dirichlet process, the multi-step hierarchical Dirichlet process (MLC-HDP), which collects simultaneously on multiple levels of a dataset. In a simulation study, we illustrate some of the advantages of this model over a similar model, the nested Dirichlet process. Finally, we show how the MLC-HDP allows us to create seizure models that take into account the importance of individual channels while integrating information from many seizures within and between patients. Such a model allows us to answer important clinical questions such as "how many seizures does this patient have?" and "what seizures does this seizure resemble other patients?," questions that to the best of our knowledge were previously unanswerable in the field of quantitative epilepsy analysis.
